writingDetail.html:
Finding a First Draft So we've finally found the beginnings of a deck "shell". No color seems stronger than our green (3X Beaver, 1X Throw From the Saddle, 1X Freestrider Lookout and 1X Cactarantula), and green is already what lets us maximize our mana with the Naturalists and Bandit.

Meanwhile, Black seems like the strongest "pairing" candidate with the green, for two main reasons: The Desert's Dues and the reanimation spells.

At this point, we want to see what this all looks like as a deck. Then we can start to figure out what that deck's missing/what it wants and how to fill those holes.

At this point, I think it's well worth laying out your pool while separating into cards that can be cast "on curve" and cards that will likely be cast "off curve". Mostly this looks like creatures vs. noncreatures, but precisely what we're looking for is how strong your deck will be at winning, or at least tying, the development stage of the game. This is why I have Desert's Dues counted in the 2-drop "creature" slot - they are a totally viable tool to use to avoid falling behind.

I've also split the Rictus Robbers between the 3-and-4 drop slots to reflect their flexibility, and am assuming Rakdos Joins Up is basically a black card that we will naturally have a few "incidental" red sources for because of our abundance of fixing.

What is this deck missing? Here's a short list:

Early pressure

We can maybe stay alive early, but we're not going to be "winning" the development stage most of the time. This means our pool will need to be able to win a grindy game.

Card advantage

We have a lot of chunky creatures and ways to recur them, which does help play a grindy game, but this deck is missing ways to go up on cards or filter away lands it draws.

Unconditional Removal

Especially in this format, you must be able to answer opposing bombs if you want to win a grindy game. Now, our Desert's Dues pull some more weight here than normal - We're going to be playing a lot of deserts, so they're much closer to Doom Blades than expensive Disfigures.

However, we'd really like at least 1-2 more universal answers. Having 4+ removal spells that can deal with a bomb ensures that we'll always draw at least 1, and usually 2 for some insurance.

Luckily, our blue and white are pretty good at solving two of these problems! Blue gives us cards and white gives us robust removal.

This is the most expansive we'll get in terms of a maindeck "shell". What I'm doing here is:

1.) Adding in the blue card advantage pieces (Loan sharks, Seize the secrets, and Siphon insight)

2.) Adding in the white unconditional removal (Buried, Journey)

3.) Creating a "sideboard" of cards that would be viable includes in our final deck, either because of raw power or potential hole-filling, but aren't necessary as part of our core

4.) Laying out our fixing, just to make sure we can still make all of this work.

That's a lot. I've basically jumped from our core GB shell that's missing a few pieces to a more expansive "mini-pool" that we're going to have to whittle down. The right deck is somewhere in between these two states. To find it, we're going to be alternating between closer and closer versions of the two until we find something cohesive and strong.

So let's take one step back towards the "smaller" version of the deck. How many cards do we have in our "skeleton" right now?

This is 25, which is already too large, so let's make it smaller. (This is a common occurence with mana-flexible pools). What don't we need here? What is redundant?

What jumps out immediately is that there are just too many 4s. The Beavers are the strongest among them and in our base color green, so we're not cutting them. The Loan Sharks are filling a card advantage hole, so we'd like to keep them ideally. The Rictus Robbers and the Rooftop Assassin are pretty redundant, so we can cut those for now (and add them back in later if appropriate!). I'm also going to cut the Rattleback Apothecary, because we have plenty of 3s, the other ones are necessary, and it's not a spectacular card.

Now we have this:

This looks a bit more balanced in terms of curve, but there are a couple things to notice.

First, we've accidentally opened up a new hole - this deck only has 11 creatures! This might not be a problem since A) The creatures we do have are beefy enough (Beavers, Sharks, Cactarantula), but we also are relying on a Throw From the Saddle and two reanimation spells, so 11 is tough to justify. I'd like at least 13.

Secondly, how many black cards are left again? 5. How many blue cards? 5. Are we sure we're base-black?

Well if the way to answer the creature count problem is adding back in the creatures we just cut, maybe we're still base-black. Or, we could instead lean heavier into the blue and play our Stoic Sphinx, the best card in the pool. This, though, makes our Desert's Dues a bit worse, and remember, they are covering our early defense, so this would come at a significant cost. It would also be another 4, which we don't really need.

The safest route seems to be thinking of this as a straight-up 3-color deck, based in green, playing equal amounts of black and blue, and opportunistically splashing some red and white. That's still quite a lot of mana requirements, so it's time to really get into the weeds of our manabase and make sure we can support it.
